channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Repeat Moviegoers Help Hollywood Eke Out a Slightly Better 2025
item.description: Ticket sales in North America totaled $8.9 billion for the year, up 2 percent from 2024. But the box office remains far below prepandemic levels.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.category: The SpongeBob Movie: Search for SquarePants (Movie)
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Movie theaters sold slightly more tickets in 2025 than in 2024, a small but meaningful uptick for a struggling industry.

item.title: Help! We Got Bedbug Bites in France, and the Luxury Hotel Won’t Admit It.
item.description: A country resort near Paris refused to cover $800 worth of medical and cleaning bills for a couple who woke up covered in bites. They’d like their stay comped, too.
item.dc:creator: Seth Kugel
item.media:credit: Charlie Padgett

item.title: How Japanese Scallops Became a Pawn in Diplomatic Tensions With China
item.description: Beijing is using a ban on the humble mollusk to punish Japan over its apparent willingness to defend Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times

item.title: An Intense White House Response From a Single Viral Video
item.description: A video purporting to expose extensive fraud at child care centers in Minnesota shows the relationship between the Trump administration and self-described citizen journalists.
item.dc:creator: Ken Bensinger and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mako Childcare Center in Minneapolis has been out of business for three years, according to Minnesota records. It was one of the places that a right-wing YouTube creator accused of fraud.

item.title: Will the A.I. Boom Continue to Drive Up Stocks in 2026?
item.description: The S&P 500 gained 16.4 percent this year. But dependence on artificial intelligence remains a risk for 2026.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: The Biggest Questions We Have for 2026
item.description: New York Times editors across the newsroom share their biggest questions as we leave 2025 behind and look ahead to 2026.
item.dc:creator: Richard W. Stevenson, Mohammed Hadi, Nestor Ramos, Nikita Stewart, Michael Mason, Gilad Thaler, David Seekamp, Lauren Pruitt, Luke Piotrowski and Edward Vega

item.title: Phone Searches at U.S. Borders: What Travelers Need to Know
item.description: Customs agents have broad authority to search the electronic devices of travelers entering and leaving the U.S. Here are tips for keeping your data safe.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root
item.media:credit: Lloyd Miller

item.title: Inside China’s Six-Decade Campaign to Dominate Rare Earths
item.description: From Deng Xiaoping to Xi Jinping, generations of Communist Party bosses and military leaders invested in a strategic but heavily polluting industry.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Fed Minutes Detail Deep Divide on Timing of Further Rate Cuts
item.description: Officials at the central bank have splintered over whether rising unemployment or elevated inflation poses the bigger economic risk.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Minutes from the Federal Reserve’s December meeting underscore Jerome H. Powell’s difficult task in forging a consensus among policymakers.

item.title: How to Put a Celebrity at Ease? Make a Pizza.
item.description: Times Cooking’s Pizza Interview series introduces a note of nostalgia to encourage stars to open up.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: Taylor Miller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Victoria Chen, a Times Cooking producer, right, made a pizza with the writer, Sarah Bahr.

item.title: Judge Rules That Trump Administration Must Continue to Fund CFPB
item.description: The Trump administration had tried to defund the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which acts as a guardrail for the safety of the financial system.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Nathan Howard/Reuters
item.media:description: In a November memo, the Justice Department wrote that the Federal Reserve could not transfer money to the C.F.P.B. because the Fed was operating at a loss.

item.title: Trump Upended the Federal Government. The Full Scope of the Impact Is Still Unclear.
item.description: President Trump achieved his goal of shrinking the work force. But many current and former officials say the government is less dependable and efficient than it was a year ago.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Environmental Protection Agency, which has lost about 25 percent of its work force, had $28 billion in grants terminated under the Trump administration.

item.title: Cheap Solar Is Transforming Lives and Economies Across Africa
item.description: Chinese panels are now so affordable that businesses and families are snapping them up, slashing their bills and challenging utilities.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Gulshan Khan
item.media:credit: Gulshan Khan for The New York Times

item.title: Katherine Maher of NPR Has Come Out on Top Despite Battles With Trump and the CPB
item.description: Katherine Maher has taken an unyielding approach to NPR’s biggest battles — which has sometimes put her at odds with her colleagues in public media.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Katherine Maher, the chief executive of NPR, has dealt with plenty of criticism this year. Did she consider quitting? “I really don’t like bullies,” she said.

item.title: Gone in 2025: A Yearlong Procession of Giants
item.description: Marquee names all, they found international fame in the arts, politics, the sciences and beyond.
item.dc:creator: William McDonald
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Leslie dela Vega/The New York Times
item.media:description: Clockwise from left: Rob Reiner, Val Kilmer, Diane Keaton, David Lynch, Robert Redford, Pope Francis and Gene Hackman.

item.title: Louis V. Gerstner, Who Revived a Faltering IBM in the ’90s, Dies at 83
item.description: Installed as an outsider, he engineered a comeback, shifting the company’s focus from a waning mainframe computer business toward consulting and services.
item.dc:creator: Steve Lohr
item.media:credit: Richard L. Harbus for The New York Times
item.media:description: Louis V. Gerstner Jr. in his office at IBM’s headquarters in Armonk, N.Y., in 2001. He was with Dr. Yvette Burton, a technology consultant.

item.title: The New Billionaires of the A.I. Boom
item.description: Just like past tech booms, the latest frenzy has produced a group of billionaires — at least on paper — from smaller start-ups.
item.dc:creator: Natallie Rocha
item.media:credit: Kimberly White/Getty Images for Wired

item.title: How Kevin Hassett Became a Trump Loyalist and Fed Chair Contender
item.description: Mr. Hassett’s evolution from conservative economist to defender of the president’s economic agenda has raised questions about how he would lead the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Colby Smith
item.category: White House Council of Economic Advisers
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kevin Hassett, director of the National Economic Council, once promoted the idea that free trade was the path to national prosperity and argued that more immigration was good for the economy.

item.title: Uber Flags Sexual Misconduct but Many Drivers Stay on the Road
item.description: The company monitors passenger feedback for risky driver behavior. Some accused of serious sexual assault had prior records of complaints.
item.dc:creator: Emily Steel
item.media:credit: Illustration by Max-o-matic; Photographs by Andres Kudacki for The New York Times, Mark Abramson for The New York Times, Shutterstock.

item.title: As Youth Sports Professionalize, Kids Are Burning Out Fast
item.description: A growing body of research shows how pressure from overbearing coaches and parents is stunting children’s emotional well-being and leading to injuries.
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: A baseball game at Kentlake High School in Kent, Wash. According to a survey by the Aspen Institute, 11.4 percent of parents believe their children can play professionally.

item.title: Meet a U.S. Start-Up Trying to Break China’s Rare-Earth Monopoly
item.description: Companies like Phoenix Tailings, which recently began producing metal in New Hampshire, are using new processing methods to compete with Chinese suppliers.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.media:description: Phoenix Tailings runs a metal-making plant in Exeter, N.H.

item.title: Exploring Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, With an Airline Pilot
item.description: On a stopover in Saudi Arabia, the writer strolls along the corniche, lingers over coffee and explores the historic heart of this city on the Red Sea.
item.dc:creator: Mark Vanhoenacker and Iman Al-Dabbagh

item.title: Gmail to Let Users Change Their Addresses While Keeping Data
item.description: Under the shift, which Google said would eventually be rolled out to all users, old addresses would remain active. Messages and services would not be lost.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Dado Ruvic/Reuters
item.media:description: Google has quietly started to roll out a way for users to change their Gmail addresses ending with @gmail.com, and keep all their emails.

item.title: What America Might Look Like With Zero Immigration
item.description: The Trump administration’s efforts to reduce the foreign-born population are being felt in hospitals and soccer leagues and on Main Streets across the country, with hints of what’s to come.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Campbell Robertson
item.media:credit: KC McGinnis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The foreign-born population in the United States hit a new high in 2024. Immigration has changed places like Marshalltown, Iowa, where some 50 dialects are spoken in the public schools.

item.title: Can You Reboot a Lamp Like a Superhero Franchise?
item.description: Riding an endless wave of nostalgia, one company is exhuming the intellectual property of midcentury designers to create new audiences for forgotten work.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe
item.media:credit: Mathias Eis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Masiello saw a business opportunity in licensing furniture designs. He’s holding a model of a chair by the Danish designer Steen Ostergaard.

item.title: Guinea Goes to Polls as Ruling Junta Seeks Legitimacy
item.description: Whoever wins faces the daunting task of feeding the West African country’s poor and navigating the interests of global powers seeking critical minerals, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Saikou Jammeh
item.media:credit: Patrick Meinhardt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A supporter dressed as Mamady Doumbouya traveling with armed escorts in Conakry, Guinea, on Thursday.

item.title: Hundreds of Flights Canceled at New York Airports, Even With a Few Inches of Snow
item.description: To avoid the ripple effects of real-time adjustments to what was predicted to be up to nine inches of snow, the major airlines said they pre-emptively canceled flights.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Gabe Castro-Root/The New York Times
item.media:description: Kennedy International Airport on Saturday morning. The airport, along with LaGuardia and Newark International, dealt with hundreds of flight cancellations and delays from Friday into Saturday.

item.title: More Student Loan Borrowers Are Shedding Debts in Bankruptcy
item.description: A new study suggests that distressed borrowers using a simpler bankruptcy process are succeeding — and that more people like them should try.
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard
item.media:credit: Moriah Ratner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amy Howdyshell, 43, used a bankruptcy filing to get more than $78,000 in federal student debt dismissed.

item.title: Before Electric Vehicles Became Political, There Was the Toyota Prius
item.description: The political polarization of battery-powered cars may have started when Toyota released its first hybrid model 25 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Lawrence Ulrich
item.media:credit: Adam Riding for The New York Times
item.media:description: The marketing for the Toyota Prius may have inadvertently started the culture war around hybrid and electric vehicles by characterizing them as a way to save the planet, some experts say.

item.title: My Job Is Making Me Sick
item.description: Plus, the long-lost art of the direct confrontation.
item.dc:creator: Max Read

item.title: How One Father Created an Organ Empire
item.description: The National Kidney Registry has matched thousands of kidney donors with recipients. It has also paid millions of dollars to a company owned by its founder.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Ivory, Grace Ashford and Robert Gebeloff
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: The organization, which began as a nonprofit, charges hospitals for access to its donor registry.

item.title: How Anthony Ramos, a ‘Hamilton’ Star, Spends a Day at His Brooklyn Bar
item.description: Anthony Ramos loves hanging out with customers during busy days that may find him writing a new musical, catching a friend in a show or performing in his own.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr and Ahmed Gaber
item.media:description: Anthony Ramos, left, at his bar, Milly’s, in Brooklyn with a friend, Kwame Onwuachi. Mr. Ramos starred in the original Broadway cast of Lin-Manuel Miranda’s “Hamilton.”

item.title: What Went Wrong Before Hong Kong’s Inferno
item.description: Records show how government departments played down residents’ warnings about corrupt practices and substandard materials that fueled the deadly blaze.
item.dc:creator: Selam Gebrekidan and Joy Dong
item.category: Prestige Construction and Engineering Co Ltd
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Wang Fuk Court apartment complex in Hong Kong days after a fire on Nov. 26 killed 161 people and displaced thousands.

item.title: A Wealth Tax Floated in California Has Billionaires Thinking of Leaving
item.description: It’s uncertain whether the proposal will reach the statewide ballot in November, but some billionaires like Peter Thiel and Larry Page may be unwilling to take the risk.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Theodore Schleifer and Heather Knight
item.media:credit: Marco Bello/Getty Images
item.media:description: Peter Thiel, a tech venture capitalist, could face a tax bill of more than $1.2 billion if the proposed wealth tax is placed on the California ballot and approved by voters.

item.title: Why Sears’s Last Great Hope Was a Promise That Never Materialized
item.description: Only five Sears stores remain in the country, with the end likely near for what was once the mightiest American retailer.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Coleman-Lochner
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: The hedge fund magnate Edward Lampert’s plan to turn Sears stores into dazzling mixed-use developments had attracted prominent investors.

item.title: As A.I. Companies Borrow Billions, Debt Investors Grow Wary
item.description: Artificial intelligence companies looking to raise funds are being made to pay lofty interest rates, as debt investors become cautious.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison
item.category: Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies
item.media:credit: Brendan Mcdermid/Reuters
item.media:description: CoreWeave, which rents data centers, is among the smaller companies bringing debt deals.

item.title: Data Center Surge Reaches India as American Tech Giants Invest Billions
item.description: Megacities in southern India are attracting enormous investments to help build artificial intelligence infrastructure to serve the world’s most data-hungry country.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Pragati K.B.
item.media:credit: Idrees Mohammed/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Microsoft’s office in Bengaluru, India. The company said it would spend $17.5 billion in India on data centers and other A.I. infrastructure.

item.title: Despite Crackdown on Activism, Tech Employees Are Still Picking Fights
item.description: They increasingly see themselves as rank-and-file workers who have traditional gripes with their companies.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Tech Workers Coalition rally this month outside the Manhattan offices of Rockstar Games, the publisher of the Grand Theft Auto video game series.

item.title: All the Cameos in ‘Marty Supreme,’ From Kevin O’Leary to Tyler, the Creator
item.description: A “Shark Tank” investor, a supermarket magnate and even N.B.A. All-Stars make appearances in the table tennis comedy.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
